body: Vin Scully is widely regarded as not just one of the greatest baseball announcers of all time, but perhaps the greatest voice in all of sport.
title: Vin Scully hints at retirement

body: Vin Scully, 85, says as long as he’s healthy, has permission from his wife and still has enthusiasm for the game, he won’t do what Dodgers fans dread: retire.
title: Vin Scully talks about returning in 2014 with the Dodgers
caption: Scully's return will mark his 65th season with the Dodgers.

body: Scully gets his first-ever Vin Scully collectible bobblehead.
title: Scully headlines the 2012 Dodger Stadium Bobblehead Series
caption: Scully looks at a rainbow before the start of a game against the Diamondbacks at Dodger Stadium.

body: Scully says he will return for another season as an announcer for the Dodgers.
title: Legendary announcer returns for a 64th season with the Dodgers
caption: Vin Scully is ready for another season with the Dodgers.

body: The first biography of Scully's life: "Pull Up a Chair: The Vin Scully Story," written by Curt Smith and published in 2009.
title: First biography is published
caption: Book cover of "Pull Up a Chair: The Vin Scully Story"

body: The Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Commission honors Vin Scully with a bronze plaque. The plaque contains the words: “The games are ephemeral, the scores are forgotten, the players come and go, but the emotions endure, and the contributions of Vincent Edward Scully to Los Angeles will last forever.”
title: The Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Commission releases a bronze plaque dedicated to Scully
caption: Photo of Vin Scully's bronze plaque, awarded by the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Commission.

body: The California Sports Hall of Fame honors Scully as one of "the biggest names in sports."
title: Scully is honored by the California Sports Hall of Fame
caption: The official logo for the California Sports Hall of Fame.

body: Scully delivers a commencement speech to the graduating class of 2008 at Pepperdine University.
title: Scully delivers a commencement speech to Pepperdine University graduates
caption: Scully, also known as “the voice of the Los Angeles Dodgers,” addressed 650 Seaver College graduates at Pepperdine University in Malibu, Calif.

body: Scully hosts “Scully & Wooden for the kids," a charity benefit at the Nokia Theatre in Los Angeles.
title: Scully hosts charity benefit event for kids at the Nokia Theatre

body: Scully stars in the 1999 Universal Pictures film “For the Love of the Game."
title: Scully stars in "For the Love of the Game"
caption: The official image for the movie "For the Love of the Game."

body: President Ronald Reagan pays a visit to the broadcaster during the Major League Baseball All-Star game.
title: President Ronald Reagan joins Vin Scully in the broadcast booth

body: Scully broadcasts 23 innings in one day in two different cities. He did the play-by-play for the NBC Game of the Week in St. Louis, then flew to call the Sunday Dodgers game, which went into extra innings.
title: Scully broadcasts 23 innings in two cities in one day
caption: Scully posing for a photo back in 1990.

body: Scully's famous call on Kirk Gibson's game-winning home run: “She is….gone!” He sits quietly has the crowd roars. Then says: "In a year that has been so improbable, the impossible has happened!"
title: Scully calls Kirk Gibson's historic home run during the 1988 World Series
caption: Kirk Gibson and Scully are seen in this photo during an event at UCLA. (Sports Illustrated photo)

body: Scully receives the Ford C. Frick Award for broadcast excellence.
title: Awarded Ford C. Frick Award for broadcast excellence
caption: File photo of Scully.

body: Vin Scully didn't just stick to baseball. Between 1975 and 1982, Scully announced National Football League games on television for CBS Sports. He is recognized for calling Dwight Clark's touchdown catch in the NFC Championship Game on Jan. 10, 1982 — putting the San Francisco 49ers into Super Bowl XVI.
title: A broadcaster with a knack for football
caption: Scully broadcasted college football games before his gig with the Dodgers in 1950. (Getty Images)

body: Some baseball broadcasters won't say that a pitcher is working on a no-hitter. Back in 1960, Vin Scully made it clear what he thought of that superstition, says the LA Times.
title: Why Scully calls no-hitters
caption: A newspaper clip published by Don Page.

body: Along with the Dodgers, Scully moves to the West Coast to cover the team's every pitch. Within a few years, he becomes a staple in Southern California.
title: Scully follows the Dodgers to the West Coast
caption: Vin Scully (right) in 1958

body: At age 25, Scully announces the 1953 World Series, making him the youngest man to broadcast a World Series game.
title: At 25, Scully becomes the youngest broadcaster to cover the World Series
caption: A young Vin Scully during a baseball game.

body: Scully is born in the Bronx on November 29, 1927. He began his broadcasting career during his time at Fordham University.
title: The birth of Vin Scully, a legendary sportscaster
caption: File photo of Vin Scully.

body: Scully marries Joan Crawford in 1958. In 1972, Crawford died from an accidental overdose.
title: Scully marries first wife Joan Crawford
caption: File photo of Joan Crawford.

body: Scully made huge waves during his stint with DC-based radio station WTOP. Shortly after, he started filling in and calling play-by-play for college football games.
title: Scully kick starts his broadcast career with DC-based radio station WTOP
caption: Scully acknowledges fans during a Dodgers' baseball game against the Cincinnati Reds in Los Angeles. (AP Photo/Mark J. Terrill, File)

body: Scully begins his career with the franchise in 1950.
title: Scully starts his first season as an announcer for the Dodgers
caption: Vin Scully during the 1950s.
